title: 110_s2105
content: The Act titled "Federal Health Care Board Act of 2007" establishes the Federal Health Care Board. The Federal Health Care Board is an independent agency in the executive branch of the United States Government. It is composed of members from the Board of Governors and 12 Regional Boards. The Board's duties include ensuring access to health insurance and providing basic healthcare services. The Federal Health Care Board aims to ensure access to health insurance and basic healthcare services. It also emphasizes the importance of transparency in pricing and quality of care provided by healthcare providers. Additionally, it seeks to establish a national standard for a basic health insurance plan. The Federal Health Care Board aims to ensure access to health insurance and basic healthcare services, emphasizing transparency in pricing and quality of care. It also seeks to establish a national protocol for secure electronic medical records, loan forgiveness and scholarship programs for providers in underserved areas, a standard for public health services, and model dispute resolution procedures for malpractice claims. The Board of Governors for the Federal Health Care Board consists of 12 members appointed by the President, one from each of the 12 regions. Appointments must be made within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Board is responsible for monitoring progress towards the objectives outlined in the Act. The Board of Governors for the Federal Health Care Board consists of 12 members appointed by the President, one from each of the 12 regions. Members serve a 14-year term and cannot be reappointed after a full term. The President appoints a Chairperson and Vice-Chairperson with the advice and consent of the Senate. The Chairperson or Vice-Chairperson of the Board of Governors serves a 4-year term. Vacancies on the Board are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and individuals appointed to fill a vacancy serve the unexpired term and may be reappointed for a full 14-year term. The Board of Governors members must have significant health care expertise in various areas. Within a year of their appointment, the Board must establish 12 regions in the United States. In each of the 12 regions established in the United States, there shall be a Regional Board composed of 8 health care experts appointed by the Board of Governors for an 8-year term. Each Regional Board must provide relevant considerations to the Board of Governors. The Board has the authority to enter contracts and make necessary arrangements. The President can detail personnel from various health departments to assist upon request. The Board established by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services must submit annual reports to Congress, including recommendations for improved policy coordination, assessment of objectives achievement, and recommendations on federal regulations. Funds are appropriated from the Treasury to carry out this section. Funds are appropriated for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 and shall remain available for expenditure through fiscal year 2012.
